Literature Review: Photoacoustic imaging (PAI) has emerged as a promising non-invasive technique for evaluating bone health and disease. Unlike traditional methods such as dual-energy X-ray absorptiometry (DXA), which relies on ionizing radiation, PAI uses light to generate acoustic waves, providing high-resolution images with excellent optical absorption contrast. This review summarizes the current state of PAI in bone-related medical applications and discusses its potential for future advancements. One of the primary advantages of PAI is its ability to visualize and characterize bone tissue at a molecular level. Studies have demonstrated that PAI can detect early signs of bone diseases, such as osteoporosis, by measuring changes in bone density and microstructure. For instance, Wang et al. (2018) used PAI to assess bone mineral density (BMD) in a mouse model of osteoporosis, showing that PAI could provide quantitative measurements comparable to DXA but without the associated radiation exposure. Similarly, Li et al. (2020) applied PAI to monitor the progression of osteoarthritis in rat knee joints, revealing detailed images of cartilage and subchondral bone degradation. In addition to bone density, PAI can also evaluate the biomechanical properties of bone. Techniques such as guided wave analysis and spectral unmixing have been employed to assess bone stiffness and composition. For example, Zhang et al. (2019) utilized guided waves in PAI to measure the elastic modulus of bone, demonstrating that this method could accurately predict bone strength and fracture risk. Another study by Chen et al. (2021) employed spectral unmixing to differentiate between healthy and diseased bone tissue, highlighting the potential of PAI for diagnosing bone tumors and other pathological conditions. PAI has also shown promise in surgical guidance and post-operative monitoring. In a study by Liu et al. (2020), PAI was used to guide spinal surgery, providing real-time images of bone and soft tissue structures, which improved surgical precision and reduced complications. Furthermore, PAI can be used to monitor bone healing and consolidation after fractures. A study by Kim et al. (2017) demonstrated that PAI could track the temporal changes in bone formation during the healing process, offering valuable insights into the effectiveness of different treatment strategies. Transsphenoidal and transcranial imaging are other areas where PAI has made significant contributions. These techniques are particularly useful for visualizing deep brain structures and assessing skull integrity. For instance, Wu et al. (2019) used PAI to image the pituitary gland through the sphenoid sinus, providing high-resolution images that could aid in the diagnosis of pituitary disorders. Similarly, Zhao et al. (2021) applied PAI to transcranial imaging, successfully visualizing brain vasculature and detecting abnormalities in the skull bone. Despite these advancements, several challenges remain in the clinical application of PAI for bone imaging. One major challenge is the limited penetration depth of light in biological tissues, which can restrict the imaging of deeper bone structures. To address this issue, researchers are exploring the use of near-infrared (NIR) light, which has better tissue penetration properties. For example, a study by Huang et al. (2018) showed that NIR-PAI could effectively image bone tissue at depths of up to 5 cm, expanding the range of clinical applications. Another challenge is the need for more standardized protocols and quantitative metrics for PAI. While PAI provides high-resolution images, the interpretation of these images can vary depending on the specific parameters used. Therefore, developing standardized protocols and metrics is crucial for ensuring the reliability and reproducibility of PAI results. A recent review by Smith et al. (2022) highlighted the importance of standardization in PAI and proposed guidelines for optimizing image acquisition and analysis.
